messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: maple + deer design tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, Please post the outcome either way.  I couldn t find anything in print to support the Takeda/Uesugi interpretation of the antler and maple leaf motif. Jim
messages.messageBody:
Tom,
Please post the outcome either way. I couldn't find anything in print to support the Takeda/Uesugi interpretation of the antler and maple leaf motif.

Jim



Milt-
You are so cute sometimes :-) In Chinese the character is
haru (Spring) but in this context is read Kasu, hi becomes ga and
hara becomes no (field). One reason, perhaps, David couldn't find any
info without the specific kanji.
As it happens I spoke to Sasama Yoshihiko Sensei the other
day and he also had not heard of any such connections between this
design and the aforementioned persons. However another friend said
that the association is connected to another design with similar
elements. I haven't an example I can point to but I was told that
when you see a single kaede leaf in opposition to a single horn
presented equal in size, the theme is still Kasuga. However there is
the added association with Takeda Shingen and Uesugi Kenshin because
the two elements in the design like the two famous generals were
equal neither able to defeat the other. He couldn't cite any sources
and it was just something he had heard. I hope to ask other
knowledgeable people in the next couple of days just to see, if they
too have heard something similar...
-t


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: maple + deer design tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... thank you, -T and Gordon, How do I know it s a name of the place instead of a  description . I did say....  Chinese reading  of the kanji. By the way,
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, tom helm <junkmail@t...> wrote:
> Milt-
> You are so cute sometimes :-) In Chinese the character is
> haru (Spring) but in this context is read Kasu, hi becomes ga and
> hara becomes no (field). One reason, perhaps, David couldn't find any
> info without the specific kanji.


thank you, -T and Gordon,
How do I know it's a name of the place instead of a " description ".
I did say.... " Chinese reading " of the kanji.
By the way, the picture text was taken from the Lundgren collection
book.
Personally I still think the association to Takeda and Kenshin is a bit
of a stretch......... but I am not going to agrue with Haynes.

-m
>

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: maple + deer design tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: For some reason my replies are not coming through. The translation of Milt s text is Kasuga-no or Kasuga-ya, which means the plains around Kasuga Shrine in
messages.messageBody:
For some reason my replies are not coming through. The translation of Milt's
text is Kasuga-no or Kasuga-ya, which means the plains around Kasuga Shrine
in Nara. There is no spring going on here at all. Just autumn, deer and
maples around Kasuga Shrine.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of David Zincavage
Sent: Wednesday, April 27, 2005 2:34 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: maple + deer design tsuba



Milt, you did not explain where this text comes from.
----- Original Message -----
From: bungotakadasword
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, April 26, 2005 7:41 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: maple + deer design tsuba



--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@s...>
wrote:
> Hi all,
>
>
>
> I have tried to find this term, but to no avail. I would like to
add,
> however, that the maple and deer motif is autumnal and not spring.
It is
> also evocative of Nara. I know of no connection with any particular
> association with a Sengoku period warlord.
>
>
>
> Gordon
>
>
>
Hi Gordon,
yes we know maples are usually associated with Autumn......however,
please klick..........
http://tinyurl.com/cxu33

Unless I am suffering from some sort of syndrome associated with
advancing age, it does read..........
Spring day in the wild ( Red leaves, deer )picture tsuba, mumei, ko-
kinko.
then yada yada yada ( the dimension etc ), 17th cent.


milt

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: maple + deer design tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I have tried to find this term, but to no avail. I would like to add, however, that the maple and deer motif is autumnal and not spring. It is also
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,



I have tried to find this term, but to no avail. I would like to add,
however, that the maple and deer motif is autumnal and not spring. It is
also evocative of Nara. I know of no connection with any particular
association with a Sengoku period warlord.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of bungotakadasword
Sent: Tuesday, April 26, 2005 2:40 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: maple + deer design tsuba




actually " kasugano " can be directly translated as " Spring day in
the wilderness "( that's the Chinese reading ).
I am sure Afu and a few others will correct me if this is wrong.

Milt

messages.subject: more deer, less maple
messages.msgSnippet: Just for interest, A lovely Kozuka by Jiryusai Tomohide, Deer and Paulownia http://world.choshuya.co.jp/sale/tousougu/choshuya/073/index.htm Deer and Pine
messages.messageBody:
Just for interest, A lovely Kozuka by Jiryusai Tomohide, Deer and Paulownia
http://world.choshuya.co.jp/sale/tousougu/choshuya/073/index.htm

Deer and Pine
http://ginzaseikodo.com/kazutsura.html

On Cary's site, this very nice Ji Sukashi tsuba ( top of thetsuba
section) Deer and Moon
http://www.ikkyudo.com

3 Deer menuki
http://www.katanadouraku.com/codougu3/c-03.html

cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: maple + deer design tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: actually  kasugano  can be directly translated as   Spring day in the wilderness ( that s the Chinese reading ). I am sure Afu and a few others will
messages.messageBody:
actually " kasugano " can be directly translated as " Spring day in
the wilderness "( that's the Chinese reading ).
I am sure Afu and a few others will correct me if this is wrong.

Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] maple + deer design tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Aha! Did a Google search, found a popular anime heroine named Kasugano; peonies, azalea, and clematis, named Kasugano, and:
messages.messageBody:
Aha! Did a Google search, found a popular anime heroine named Kasugano; peonies, azalea, and clematis, named Kasugano, and:

http://www.miho.or.jp/booth/html/imgbig/00005474e.htm

Evidently the name KASUGANO refers to the Kasuga shrine at Nara:

http://www.jyh.or.jp/english/kinki/narakasu/

David


----- Original Message -----
From: bungotakadasword
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, April 25, 2005 9:42 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] maple + deer design tsuba



Hi David,
You are interested in this particular design..........
while looking at the lundgren collection book, tsuba #126, is a ko-
kinko tsuba with maple + deer design.
Comments by Ogasawara and Kobayashi did not mention anything about
Takeda and Uesugi, but they called this theme " Kasugano ".
Just thought you may want to know.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] maple + deer design tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you. Unfortunately, I don t own the Lundgren book, as yet.  I have seen a Shoami tsuba with the same theme in Torigoye or Sassano.  I tried looking up
messages.messageBody:
Thank you.

Unfortunately, I don't own the Lundgren book, as yet. I have seen a Shoami tsuba with the same theme in Torigoye or Sassano. I tried looking up KASU in Nelson without success, but it's good to have the term. They probably have a term for your monkey-in-peach-tree too, wouldn't you suppose?

David
